description:
The object of the game is to position your own dice in a row next to each other. The dice must be in a straight line, not around a corner. They may be in any numerical order.

A simple dice strategy game for all ages.
publishers: APEX Spiel und Hobby, Spear's Games

name: My First Scrabble
description:
Children will enjoy playing this game and have no idea that they are learning to spell - they'll just enjoy the game !

The full alphabet is divided into groups of coloured tiles. The words are similarly colour coded so that a child shouldn't be put off finding a letter in a particular word if you show them that they just need to look at the colour of the letter first. Then they only have to search for the correct letter out of a small group of letters all the same colour instead of the whole alphabet. Children will be keen to show they can do it by just finding the letter rather than the colour. Level 1 just starts spelling words like 'cat' whilst higher levels move onto 'pear' and bean' showing different sounds made by 'ea'.

name: Megabuck$
description:
From the manual:

"Outsmart other corporate wheeler dealers and avoid bankruptcy! Capitalize on the ups and downs of a fluctuating economy! Climb the corporate ladder and become a megabucks big shot!"

Players roll and move around the game board buying chairs in various companies or triggering a range of events such as Depression, Inflation, Boom and Bust. Interestingly, the game time is set at the beginning. The winner is the player with the most cash on hand combined with the current value of the various chairs of each company they're on.

It's an Australian game and most of the companies are either Australian or multi-national.

The game box contains the game board, a rules leaflet, scrip (of various denominations), a dividend schedule card, 6 player markers, 150 small pawn markers (25 for each player), an economic indicator marker and two dice of contrasting colors.
This is an Australian published game based on the Monopoly theme. The board has a circular track with a number of spaces representing Australian & International businesses (of which all contributed to have the game published). A portion of each company may be purchased by players landing on the relevant space (called 'chairs'), to a maximum of three. The cost of 'chairs' are controlled by the current economic climate, which can vary. Cash is received from players landing on businesses owned by other players ('rents'), using a multiplier depending on the number of chairs owned. Other spaces on the board control the economic climate, income & sales tax payments, receiving dividends & buying or selling of new chairs.
The game ends after a pre-determined time (90 minutes is suggested in the rules leaflet), at which time the player with the largest net worth wins (consisting of cash on hand plus the current value of chairs).
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding
publishers: Megabucks International Pty.Ltd, Response Advertising Pty. Ltd.

name: Kerala
description: Kerala is a race game from Asia. Two or three players move their five pieces around a course, dictated by the throws of five cowrie shells. The board consists of a square perimeter track and three "runways" approaching a corner, through which pieces enter and exit the board. The object of the game is to be the first to move one's pieces onto the board via a runway, around the course to the centre, around the course again and bear off via the runway.

name: I Spy "Word Scramble" Game
description: From the publisher: "Do you spy a face? Green eyes? A grin? Slide the letters in place! SCRAMBLE! You win! I Spy Word Scramble has won many awards since its debut, including iParenting Media Award and Nick Jr. Best Toy Award."

name: Monopoly: Red Sox 2007 World Series Champions
description: A limited edition Monopoly game for 2 to 6 players ages 8 and up. Features unique playing pieces designed for the team.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Pingi
description: Penguins move from ice floe to ice floe. Clever usage of the rolled numbers moves little ice floes which make the course for the 12 penguins - a player moves either his floes or his penguins with one die - the penguins try to reach the large ice floe - but their small ice floes can be robbed by the other players, when a six is rolled.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Räuber und Gendarm
description:
Content:
4 robbers (wooden),
1 policeman,
die,
board

4 robbers heavily loaded with valuable treasures try to creep home through the forest. But the path to the robbers' cave is not easy to travel, because the gendarme are already following them. Will the robbers be able to bring their treasures home safely? Everyone tries to bring its robber with the accumulated valuable treasure to the hiding place first.

name: 't Geheugen van een Olifant
description: Object of the game: Keep possession of Play-cards by remembering exactly where the 12 images are hidden. 12 different images are hidden under blue 'caps' During the game they move from one place to another. The oldest player starts this game. Throw the dice en move your pon over the track on the board. Execute the command which is stated by an pictogram. You either have to point out the right and exact location of the number or image that is stated on the track. The tricky thing is that the caps move around the board as a result of some orders. Some orders on the track are simple, and need you to pin point 1 image or number. Other orders force yoy to point out for example, 3 fruits or 3 figures. Every player has 3-7 playcards. everytime they slip out during the game by not pointing out the right items, they loose one playcard (it is flipped to the stop-side). The player who keeps at least one card in play while the others are played out, wins the game.

name: Monopoly: Erfurt
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Erfurt, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Kunststück Krimi-Kartenspiel
description:
From the Box:
"There is no heist too difficult for a true master thief. Not even breaking into art museums and stealing the most valuable paintings. Names like da Vinci, Rembrandt or Van Gogh are the pieces that dubious collectors want to have and these promise high earnings.
But beware: Other thieves also have their eyes on the best pieces. Only the one who is able to hide his spoil, dodges the raids from the police and is clever enough to sell the acquired art to the highest bidder will make the BIG business!"

name: Chronalyst
description:
Chronalyst offers timed trick-taking madness for 3-4 players.

Players are chemists trying to earn and put together the best compounds using chemical cards in four different colors. Each set begins with a dice roll, determining the extra value of the four different chemicals.

At the end of the game, players have thirty seconds to put together the best compounds using the chemicals they've acquired through the game, and lose points for the chemicals they don't use.

name: Delugio
description:
Working with a partner, each of you equipped with just a wooden stick, prove your dexterity by rescuing the maximum number of living species and moving them to safety on the little wooden bridge. Manual skills and speed are needed to play this wooden game which is sure to please big and small "Noah's" who want to preserve the planet's biodiversity!

Contents
32 Wooden Sticks
1 Wooden Footbridge
9 Animals and Vegetables Pawns
1 Wooden Spinning Top
Game Rules

name: Carrera's chess
description:
Carrera's chess was a chess variant created by Pietro Carrera, 17th century priest and historian from Sicily.

Carrera's chess was played on an 8x10 chessboard with two new pieces: a "champion" (a combination of a rook and a knight) and "centaurus" (a combination of a bishop and a knight). It was a predecessor of Capablanca chess.

There is no castling is this version of chess. Pawns may make an initial double step, but not if they could be taken en passant by the rules of orthodox chess and at the same time block a check.

name: Elite Penguin Force Card Game
description:
The EPF needs you! Use EPF Agents to solve Field-Ops and earn medals. The first agent to collect 5 Field-Op medals wins. Good luck!

Basic gameplay:
All Field-Ops are shuffled, and the top card of this Field-Op deck is put in the centre of the table. All other cards are shuffled too, and every player gets 5 cards from this Agent Deck. With the youngest player starting, every player now tries to fulfill (one of) the requirement(s) on the Field-Op card to claim it for one or more medals. If not possible, that player draws a card from the Agent Deck, and tries again. If again not possible, it becomes next player's turn. If possible, then you put the Field-Op in question in front of you, discard all cards used to fulfill the requirement in question, put the next Field-Op from the Field-Op Deck into play and draw back up to 5 cards from the Agent Deck. Play continues until one player has accumulated a total of 5+ Field-Op medals.

Box contents:
55 cards (36 normal penguin agent cards, 10 Field-Op mission cards, 9 other agent cards)
1 code card (to unlock items in Club Penguin)
1 rules booklet

name: Tap the Frog
description:
Tap the Frog, based on the app of the same name, is a collection of games in which players bounce balls on the table and try to have them land in particular cells in a grid that lies in the bottom of the box.

• In "Froschball", players take turns bouncing a ball off the table while trying to have it land on frogs within the grid. If a ball doesn't land in the box after three tries, remove it from the game. Once all the balls are thrown, players score two points for each ball on a frog of the same color, 1 point for a ball on a frog of different color, 0 points for a ball on water, and -2 points for a ball on a pirate.

• "Solohüpfer" is a solo variant with the same scoring system in which the player tries to maximize his score.

• In "Bälle-Schubser", a ball doesn't score if it shares a grid space with a ball of a different color. Otherwise, scoring is identical to "Froschball" and the player with the most points after five rounds wins.

• In "Tic Tac Trio", players take turns bouncing balls into the grid — retrieving one ball from the grid first if all balls have been thrown — and the first player to place three in a row wins.

Tap the Frog has a double-sided pond, with one side having a single pirate and the other having two pirates and more water spaces.

name: Crap or Slap! What Would You Do?
description: Crap or Slap! What Would You Do? tests each person's ability to tolerate the strange, the frightening or the annoying. How would you react if... "You wake up in the middle of the night and find a giant tarantula crawling on your bed" or "A vampire starts to sparkle"? The game comes with 250 cards, both containing a situation and a reaction. Active player picks a situation (or a reaction in round 2) and you try to figure out how that person would react (or which situation would prompt that reaction in round 2).

name: Ciudadano Ilustre
description:
Ciudadano Ilustre is a trivia game about six subjects: politics, health, natural resources, education, population and work (all about Argentina). The questions do not evaluate only academic knowledge, but the ability to derive the right answer. There are also cards that can alter the rules of the game.

Players receive secret objectives at the beginning of the game (e.g., to have 3 points in politics) that give extra points. Players take turns answering, until one of them gets 12 points.

name: Ninja All-Stars: Sun Empire Wandering Samurai
description:
The Sun Empire Wandering Samurai is a mercenary ronin for Ninja All-Stars. Ronin bring potent new abilities to a player’s team that are entirely unique to them. As mercenaries, ronin may be used by any player, on any team. This makes ronin invaluable assets for every team, regardless of clan, since they may be used to supplement a team’s weaknesses in battle or further augment their strengths.

Ever watchful for weakness, the Sun Empire’s agents can turn up anywhere, and discovering them and sending them politely on their way has become a game among many clans. The Sun Empire Wandering Samurai is but one of the many skilled warriors that has surfaced in Kagejima, offering services to interested parties. Such is the cut-throat nature of Kagejima’s politics—especially the prestige attached to the Moonlight Tournament—that they often find those willing to employ them.

Highlights:

Introduces Unique Abilities
Fully Assembled Model
Peerless and Precise Mercenary Ronin
categories: Adventure, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor, Miniatures, Sports, Video Game Theme

name: Barabistouille
description: Each player plays a character and receives 3 capsules to vote and reward the best improvisations. Throughout the game, you have to improvise on different subjects and themes. The goal ? Live in the somebody elses's skin!

name: Handimonium: The Tiny Hands Game
description:
Players or teams compete to see who can complete the most tasks while using the small, doll-like hands provided.

There are three different ways to play the game: Relay, Battle, and Charades. You can choose how you want to play depending on how many players you have. Each of the Challenge cards includes a challenge that can be used in Relay or Battle gameplay and one Charade.

In Relay play, which is for four or more players, teams compete to be the first to complete five challenges using the tiny hands. Player 1 on the team does the first challenge, and then passes the hands to player 2 who completes the second challenge and passes the hands to the third player for the third challenge, and so on. The first team to finish five challenges wins.

If you only have two players, you can Battle. Players go head-to-head to see who can complete a challenge first. You score one point if you do. The first player to earn five points wins.

And for three or more players, you can play Charades. The acting player uses the tiny hands to act out the clue on the Challenge card while the other players try to guess the answer. You can add a one- or two-minute time limit, if you want. The player who guesses right gets one point, and so does the acting player. The first player to earn five points wins.

name: Mein Kirschbaum
description:
Each player gets a tree in a garden and a bucket. First each player hangs 10 cherries in his/her tree. At the players turn he/she turns the arrow on the disk and acts according the field where the arrow stops. Either picking 1 – 4 cherries if it lands on the cherry fields, or if it lands on a field with a bird or a dog you loose 2 cherries and have to hang them back on the tree. If it lands on the field with the tipped basket you have tho hang all the cherries back on the tree. Winner is who collects first 10 cherries of his/her tree.

Jeder Spieler bekommt einen Baum in einem Garten und einen Eimer. Zuerst hängt jeder Spieler 10 Kirschen in seinen Baum. Beim Drehen des aktuellen Spielers dreht er/sie den Pfeil auf der Scheibe und handelt entsprechend dem Feld, in dem der Pfeil landet. Entweder pflücken man 1-4 Kirschen, wenn es auf den Kirschfeldern landet, oder wenn es auf einem Feld mit einem Vogel oder einem Hund landet, verlieret man 2 Kirschen und man muss sie wieder an den Baum hängen. Wenn es auf dem Feld mit dem gekippten Korb landet, müssen Sie alle Kirschen wieder an den Baum gehängt werden. Gewinner ist, wer als erster die 10 Kirschen seines Baumes sammelt.

name: Army of Zero
description:
Army Of Zero is a card and dice game in which two players pit their team of warriors against each other. Players use their judgement to pick the right character to use at the right time, and second-guess their opponent to choose when to attack and when to defend. The game is designed to be quick and easy to both learn and play, encouraging children and their parents to play together.

But Army of Zero also holds a secret. The game's unusual feature is that the deck of eighty-four character cards hides a series of puzzles. The person who submits the best solution before the closing date will win a cash prize.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Puzzle
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Who Is The Thief?
description: This is a children's card game in which cards representing Suspects and Witnesses are played until only one Suspect and the Stolen Diamond Necklace is left--this person is the Thief. An interesting concept where there is no winner--only one loser.

name: Snoopy Flying Ace Game
description: The world's most beloved beagle is back! A legend in his own mind. Snoopy takes off as the Flying Ace in constant pursuit of his nemesis; The Red Baron. It's high-flying fast-paced fun around the Eiffel Tower as Woodstock and his team of mechanics lend support from the ground. Pick up the most tiles to win!.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Real-time
mechanics: Action Queue, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Yamunda
description: In Yamunda, players are expedition members who are searching for unusual creatures – and now they've discovered an incredibly bewildering variety of life around the Yamunda, a small river region in the Amazon. Whoever collects the most objects by the end of this journey will be the most successful expedition member and the winner of this game.

name: Fairy Mischief
description:
Designed by Jay and Susie Hernishin for their daughter, Fairy Mischief is a light game designed to help younger gamers transition into more advanced gaming with the goal of making more girl analog gamers!

Players take on the roles of fairies competing in displays of magic. The fairies will duel one another over colorful gem pieces that are randomly drawn from a satchel (watch out for the powerful black stones that grant special abilities). When one fairy has won a gem of each of the five colors, they win!

The basic game uses the classic game of War (players win duels by flipping over the top three cards of their deck and comparing who has the highest cards in a best-of-three fashion) combined with other elements to introduce the players to "gamery" skills (collection, special powers, and randomness).

There are also more advanced ways to play, so the game can grow with or adapt to kids. New concepts include (push-your-luck, hand ranks, informed guessing, discard pile awareness, etc.)
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Fantasy

name: scene it?
description: More than 70 years of soccer history in one quiz game! You watch a film clip randomly chosen and answer some questions about the world championships till 2006.

name: Commerce
description:
This game is from 1900 and was published by the J. Ottmann Litho Company of New York.

The directions say that Commerce is "the most amusing game on the market"

The game is comprised of a deck of cards with 8 suits
(Pork, Sugar, Cotton, Corn, Coffee, Oats, Flour and Butter) of 6 cards in each suit, making 48 cards in all.

After shuffling the cards, deal each player 6 cards. Each player sorts the cards that they have and then decides which suit they will try to corner.

The object of the game is to obtain all of the cards of one suit by trading with other players.

To play you take from your hand a card or cards of similar suite and holding them up call "Trade 2 or trade 3. All players do that at the same time so there is lots of yelling going on. Sorta like what happens on the New York Stock Exchange. People make trades of cards. So you could trade 2 with someone else then find that the 2 that you receive match a card or two that you already have in your hand and now you might try and trade 3 for 3. When the first player succeeds in getting all of the cards in a suit the player calls "corner" shows the cards to everyone else. First player to get 3 corners wins!
categories: Card Game, Economic, Party Game, Real-time

name: Thomas & Friends Tipsy Topsy Turvy Game
description:
This is a dexterity game based on the classic Thomas Tank Engine cartoon. The board is a 3-D railroad track display with a Thomas engine and a freight car. Players take turns drawing freight tiles. Each child must place the matching item (barrel, logs, etc.) or place an item of the matching color. The stack grows more unstable as the game continues. Other cards require a child to rotate the track, and this can cause the pile to tumble.

Items that fall off of the pile are returned to play. When the last tile in the deck has been flipped over the game ends. The player who successfully placed the most items is declared the winner.

name: #AlternativeFacts
description:
Welcome to the post-fact world of lucrative headline crafting! You and your team of genius entrepreneurs must work together to make the most clickbaiting headlines possible. Is this a cooperative game? Hell no! You want to win the headline by contributing the best card to it, so screw those other guys.

In #AlternativeFacts, each card has a noun, verb, or adjective on it, plus a Clickbait Strength number and possibly a Hot-button icon. You and the other players will use the cards to construct a single headline.

The game is played in rounds, where each player takes their turn playing a single card to the headline that is forming in the middle of the table. Once the headline has 2 Hot-button icons in it, the round ends. Read the headline out loud. The player who has the WINNING! card in front of them wins the round and takes a card from the headline and adds it to their score pile. The 1st player to collect 7 cards this way wins!

name: Task Forces at War
description: Task Forces at War is a really quick card game for two, pitting the Axis' and Allies' naval vessels against one another. Players secretly and simultaneously select three ships from their hand of five, then reveal the chosen three. Each ship has three combat values, namely aircraft, big guns, and torpedoes. If there are four or more aircraft carriers, then the battle will be a carrier battle, and all ships use their aircraft. If, instead, there are five or more battleships, all ships will use their big guns. Otherwise, the ships will employ their torpedoes. Once the type of battle is identified, the players total their combat strengths, then compare them. The player with the higher total sinks one of the opponent's ships. Generally, the loser selects the ship to sacrifice; however, if the winner has double or more the combat value of the loser, then the winner sinks whichever ship she likes. Once the decks are exhausted, the round is complete, and the player who has sunk the higher total victory point value of ships wins the round. Winning two rounds wins the game.

name: Holiday
description:
In this game you can travel through Europe. The goal of the game is to travel with all your 3 people to the 4 randomly chosen countries (different for each player) and return to the starting country, Hungary.
You can travel by car, airplane or ship and you can earn money by gambling, working, playing detective or collecting sets of several kinds of building tokens (bank, museum, etc).

name: Challenge Sudoku
description: 50 different Sudoku challenges. Three different ways to play: Standard, Challenge and Solitaire Sudoku.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Warte und pass auf!
description:
"Wait and watch - my first Traffic game" is a dice game for teaching traffic rules to preschool and early primary school children.

A double sided board depicts 2 street scenes - 1 side showing a street with a zebra (pedestrian) crossing and the other side a street without a crossing but with 4 "waiting" zones. The players must move via dice rolls from their homes on one side of the street to the color-specific goal on the other side (e.g. bakery, playground, sweetshop etc).

A large wooden dice controls movement but 2 sides show a car symbol which if rolled, result in the cars moving along the road. Meeples can't cross the street unless they finished their last turn in a waiting square at the side of the road and only if both cars have passed by or are stopped at the zebra crossing waiting.

Contents:
1 double sided board
1 large dice sides: 2, 3, 3, 4, car, car
4 colored meeples : blue, pink, green, yellow
2 wooden cars
1 instruction booklet
publishers: Otto Maier Verlag, Ravensburger, Το Καλό Παιχνίδι Α.Ε.

name: Xhenor
description: Qalgon, the despicable wizard-prince of Xhenor, feeling the end of his abomination-ridden reign nearing, decided to settle his succession. Play the part of one his 6 overly ambitious children, using manipulation, bluff, alliances and treasons, power, gold, and unlimited Machiavellianism in order to get the fifth ring of knowledge, and be hailed as the Great Xhenocrat; but the overall balance of the Kingdom must be maintained and the timely match of the various races populating the fantasy world.

name: Mouse Island
description:
Mouse Island is a children's strategy game (Ages 5 and up) for two players created by Donald Green, the designer of Octi. In his words, "It's a game where mice scurry across a bed of dominoes in order to reach the cheese on the other side. On each turn, players move their mouse and a domino, so that the geometry of the island is always changing."

The game contains all wooden components: ten two-space tiles (referred to in the above description as "dominoes"), two cheese disks, and two different mice disks.

name: UNO: Hulk
description:
Basic Uno-themed card game.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The "Gamma Blast" card. This card works like a wild card and also the player may designate himself or another player to put their hand under the Gamma Blast card and then draw that same amount of cards form the draw pile. They then discard the Gamma Blast along with their original hand and play continues.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Schau Genau
description: Schau Genau is an image matching game for children. The first player to properly place her sixteen tiles on the board wins. Afterwards, a transparent foil is used to check the completed board. If images were matched correctly, then marks on the tiles line up with marks on the foil.
publishers: Jumbo Manufacturing Pty. Ltd., Otto Maier Verlag

name: High 5
description:
"High 5" is a party game that, like the more popular "Cranium" which it pre-dates, combines five party-style games into one.

Players (or teams) roll four 10-sided dice to generate a four-digit number that corresponds to a question in "The Book of 10,000 Questions." The number also indicates which of the five categories of game type the player will have. The categories are: "Pic-Wit" (Pictionary) "Bull-Wit" (Balderdash) "Ham-Wit" (Charades) "Sher-Wit" (20 Questions) and "Wiz-Wit" (Trivia).

The question book indicates how many spaces the players advance. In some situations, both the players asking the questions and the players responding will be able to advance. In other situations, an incorrect answer will send a player backwards along the track.

Questions for younger players are included in the question book, allowing players to create an easier game for children.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Piremid
description: The object of the Piremid game is to race your opponents around the board by attempting to get your Sarcophagus to the Pharaoh's Tomb first and then build a Pyramid. The game is played on a playing board representing ancient Egypt and consists of four different sections: the City, the Quarry, The River Nile and the Desert. These four sections have to be negotiated before entering The Valley Of The Kings, whereupon a player may attempt to build a Pyramid. The first player to successfully complete a Pyramid is the winner of the game.

name: Petrodólares
description: A Monopoly like game. Players are oil tycoons making business around the world to get the best concesions.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Cranium: Humdinger
description:
A fast paced cooperative play game where you have to name the tune. Work together as a team to hum and guess all the answers before time runs out.

Easy to modify if there are large amounts of players or the players are quick to guess the answers: just pull out more cards and continue until timer is up.

name: Killer Bunnies Odyssey Promo Cards
description:
Promo Cards are distributed at conventions, bunny promotions and special bunny events. Some cards are distributed when you buy your game through Playroom Entertainment or from select retailers.

There are seven copies of each promo card: one for each color deck with a cost requirement relating to their corresponding color, and one with colorless cost requirements. For the colored cards, the "X" is replaced by the letter corresponding to the deck that they belong to.

Triple Bunny (Available with some purchases of A-Decks)
AX61/AW01: Triple Bunny allows a player to add (+3) Civ Points to his d20 die at the start of each turn if the player has three Triple Bunny cards in The Bunny Circle.

Time Circuits (AX62 available with 3-Pack Starter Decks; AW02 available with Killer Bunnies and the Conquest of the Magic Carrot)
AX62/AW02: Time Circuits may be used once by a player to add Civ Points to his d20 die equal to the number that the player rolls on the d12 die if it matches the number value of the current minute, hour (AM or PM), day, month or year (last two digits).

Onyx Lotus (Available with some purchases of C-Decks)
AX63/AW03: Onyx Lotus may be used for one turn by a player as any three saved Resource cards.

Female Mating Bunny (Available with some purchases of B-Decks)
BX31/BW01: Identical to BX01/BX02, but with different art. (Note that both versions are misprinted.)

Point Of Hue
BX32/BW02: Point Of Hue may be used once by a player to force any one opponent to trade any one of his bunnies in The Bunny Circle for any saved Resource cards from the player equal to the bunny’s point value. The player chooses the bunny and the saved Resource cards.

Wonka Chocolate - Bunny Modifier (Available with some purchases of Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot: Chocolate Booster)
BX33/BW03: Wonka Chocolate may be placed under any bunny in play and coats the bunny in chocolate. Any player may consume the bunny to satisfy any Feed The Bunny card. No Civ Points are awarded to any player.

Psych-Out Bunny (Available with some purchases of C-Decks)
CX31/CW01: Identical to CX02, but with different art. (Both versions are misprinted.)

Night at the Roxbunny
CX32/CW02: Night At The Roxbunny may be used once by a player only after sunset and before sunrise to take any two cards from his Discard Pile and to shuffle them back into his Draw Pile.

Peter Venkbunny
CX33/CW03: Peter Venkbunny may be used once by a player to force all opponents to take any card with a Symbol out of their five-card hand and to place it face down. For each card, the player attempts to guess the Symbol. If correct, the opponent subtracts (-1) Civ Point and the player adds (+1) Civ Point to his d20 die. The player rolls the d6 die once to determine how many times (per card) that he may guess.

Sighter Bunny
DX31/DW01: Identical to DX03 and DX04, but with different art.

Tear Me a New One
DX32/DW02: Tear Me A New One may be used once by a player to either add (+1) Civ Point to his d20 die or tear this card in half and add (+5) Civ Points to his d20 die. The player must actually own this card if he wishes to tear it in half. This card may not be repaired and used again after it has been torn.

Flame On
DX33/DW03: The player with Flame On saved may sacrifice this card to eliminate the burn cost for any Double Ground Weapon, Triple Ground Weapon, Double City Weapon or Triple City Weapon card. The Card Cost of the weapon (without the burn cost) must still be paid. Flame On must be a saved Special to be used immediately. The Card Cost is paid when this card is saved.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor

name: Elephant Memo
description:
The baby elephants hide under the pedestals of the adult elephants, waiting to be found. Whoever finds the most baby elephants wins the game.

A children's game for 2 to 5 players, ages four and up. Players roll a die and try to locate cute platic elephants of the matching colour, hiding under little pedestal cups. A simple game of memory for children.

While this has a memory element, it is not another version of Memory. It uses a die to select what color elephant to attempt to locate under the pedestals. The pedestals are a scoring device. Players do not need to match pairs, just simply locate an elephant. If you don't locate a match, you grow the pool of elephants by one of your own pedestals. If you run out of pedestals, you're out of the game. Last player standing, or first player to successfully locate a set number of elephants, wins.

name: Game Developerz: E-Sports
description: A 33-card expansion, that includes new companies, pro players, and E-Sport events and competitions.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Video Game Theme

name: Braiiiins!
description:
Braiiiins is a 1-6 player game where you control one of six different zombie characters. There are currently 4 different missions to be completed and 2 different modes (Co-op and an indirect player versus player.

Each turn is broken up into three rounds: spawn, locate, and then feed.

During the spawn round, players will all look at the spawning rules for the zombie character they have choosen. Then will then draw a number of zombie allies from the risen deck based on those rules.

During the locate round, players will draw living cards from the living deck. The number of living cards drawn is based on the number of players who started the game. These are who the zombies will feed on!

During the feed round, the players then assign their zombie character and risen cards up against the living cards that are currently in play. Attack and defense characteristics are compared to one another to see who wins the fight! After all fighting actions are resolved, the game turn starts over again.

There are several ways to win: in player versus player mode, you want to be the zombie who has taken the least amount of damage. In our co-op mode, you must successfully complete the choosen scenario before running out of hit points.

Our scenarios range from eliminating the entire town of Risington, to picking off specific members of the town!

name: Garbage Pail Kids: Super Snot Shots
description:
Garbage Pail Kids: Super Snot Shots supports 2-4 players and is a dexterity game that involves flicking dice (that represent snot) at a target. Each player chooses one of the four snot-covered Leaky Lindsay cards and a six-sided die of the same color, then takes a position around a target card. The cards in the game are all squares with rounded edges; they feature eleven Garbage Pail kids, all featuring classic Garbage Pail Kids art, everyone from Surf's Up Chuck to Dead Ted to Mark Barf.

You make a draw pile out of the cards and select one to be a target, placing it in the middle of everyone and placing your Leaky Lindsay card two card-lengths away. Once set-up is complete, count down "3, 2, 1, SHOOT!", then flick your die from your Lindsay card towards the target card, trying to aim it so that your die stops on top of it. If only one player gets her die on the target card, she claims it; if two or more dice land on the card, then whoever has the highest number showing on her die wins it; if no one lands on the card, then it's a tie and everyone shoots again!

The game continues until no cards remain, and whoever has the most cards wins.

name: Prove It!
description: Prove It! is a game of myths and evidence for 2-5 players. each player attempts to prove the existence of some of the world's most mysterious creatures including: Bigfoot, Merfolk, Vampires, and many more. This is achieved by playing evidence on your myth while attempting to discredit and disprove your opponent's myths. The first player to 8 victory points is the winner!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Humor, Mythology, Party Game

name: Trust Me, I'm Psychic
description:
Do you believe psychics can glimpse into the future or that all psychics are frauds? The mystical and hysterical game of Trust Me, I'm Psychic might change your thinking!

In this unpredictable game of predictions, one player acts as the Customer, asking a question about their future that the Psychics must answer. All other players act as Psychics, and are dealt a Vision card that tells them if they are a true Psychic or a Fraud. All the players who are true Psychics see the same tarot-inspired image that they can use to craft a fortune for the customer. The Frauds do not see the picture, and will just have to wing it (with some help from the Cursed Words clues on their card)!

The Customer asks a question on any subject about his or her future. Will I win the lottery? Will I find true love this year? Whether you are a Psychic or a Fraud, use your imagination to spin a fantastical fortune for the Customer. Of course, fortune-telling is not as easy as it seems. Psychics and Frauds must avoid speaking the forbidden Cursed Words listed at the bottom of their cards. If your fellow Psychics/Frauds catch you saying a Cursed Word, you'll get a Curse Token.

If you tell a convincing fortune the Customer rewards you with a token and gets to look at your card. If the Customer chose a true Psychic, they can use the image on the card to deduce who the remaining Psychics are. But if the Customer accidentally pays a Fraud, he or she gets a Curse Token.

The game ends after each player has a turn being the Customer. The player with the most money tokens (after subtracting Curse Tokens)wins!

—description from the publisher

name: I Wish I Didn't Know!
description:
ADULTS ONLY: This game contains mature content and is designed for ages 17+. NOT intended for children. Trust us.

I WISH I DIDN’T KNOW: Compete with your friends and family by guessing which gross fact is actually true. Just read off the answer choices and hear your audience groan! By the end, you’ll all be experts on all things you wish you didn’t know. Brought to you by the creators of What Do You Meme.

HOW TO PLAY: Players rotate drawing a trivia card while the rest of the group competes to guess which answer is correct. Once everyone has guessed, the judge reveals the correct answer and awards one point to those who chose correctly. The player with the most points at the end of the game takes the crown.

WHAT’S INSIDE: Contains 500 trivia cards plus instructions. Printed on premium playing cards (thick with gloss finish), shrink-wrapped in a custom box.

—description from the designer

name: Monopoly: Discover
description:
The Monopoly Discover board game offers fun teaching tools for families. It features a double-sided gameboard with 2 levels of play, so you can decide which level is right for the family! One side focuses on counting and matching, recommended for kids ages 4-5. Flip the board over for more advanced play, focusing on reading and simple math, recommended for kids ages 6 and up. Gameplay in each level uses its own set of Monopoly money and cards, as well as rules. Inspired by Monopoly classic gameplay -- after all, every billionaire starts somewhere! The game is a great choice for a family game night, and makes a fun gift for kids ages 4 and up. The Hasbro, Hasbro Gaming, Parker Brothers, and Monopoly names and logos, the distinctive design of the gameboard, the four corner squares, the Mr. Monopoly name and character, as well as each of the distinctive elements of the board and playing pieces are trademarks of Hasbro for its property trading game and game equipment.


LEARN, EARN, AND GROW: It's a game that grows with kids! The Monopoly Discover board game presents playful teaching tools for families
2 LEVELS OF PLAY: The 2-sided gameboard offers 2 levels of play: One side focuses on counting and matching for little kids. Flip the board over for a focus on reading and simple math for big kids
ADORABLE MONOPOLY TOKENS: Kids will love using the Monopoly tokens: Penguin, Car, Ducky, Scottie, Hazel, and Rex
2 SETS OF MONEY AND CARDS: Each level includes its own set of Monopoly money and cards, appropriate for that level
SIMPLIFIED MONOPOLY GAMEPLAY: From the makers of Monopoly Junior, this board game is designed to be fast, fun, and an exciting game for kids ages 4 and up


—description from the publisher
mechanics: Income, Ownership, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Charivari
description: The game contains 800 cards with scrambled words and clues. Players have 10 seconds to uncover the scrambled word, if they fail, they get a clue and 10 more seconds. The less clues a player needs, the more points he gets. The first player to reach 2500 points is the winner.

name: Grabitz
description:
Grabitz is a commercial version of the traditional card game Spoons.

Players collect cards trying to spell "Grab" using either cards all from one color or cards with only a single letter each but of any color. Once a player has accomplished this, they grab one of the hands in the middle of the table. Everyone else then grabs one too as quickly as possible. The player left without a hand gets marks scored against him.

Once a player has enough marks to spell "Grabitz", he/she is eliminated. The last one standing wins.

name: Pocket Enigma
description:
From the back of the box:
"Refreshingly different, POCKET ENIGMA is the perfect game for TWO adults.

"It's a race to the centre, BUT with a twist; you can sabotage your opponent. See them squirm as you move them back. Yes, at long last the pocket game that brings out the scoundrel in us all.

"The Riddle is the key - the NEW Challenge of the 90's. Some are easy, some fiendishly difficult. Can't solve them? Ask for a clue and see who your friends really are."

Pocket Enigma is a small version of the Enigma game of riddles, with a small board inside the box lid, two pieces, a dice, some instructions, and 500 riddles. The objective is to move your gaming piece through a maze, from a starting point on the outer edge of the board, to the finishing point, at the center of the board. Players take it in turns to roll a die and move their pawn the indicated number of spaces along the track. There are special spaces along the track where a player is asked to solve a riddle.

It is a stand alone game , but it also states on the box that this is an expansion for the original game, adding 500 new riddles to the original.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Living Dead Dolls Board Game
description: Bring your worst enemies together for a deadly adventure. Be the first player to survive the savage lands of the Living Dead Dolls and reach the mausoleum. Using brilliantly twisted playing cards you can buy and trade souls, cast spells, posses opponents, freeze opponents and even morph into the leader the deadly pack. Contents include: Game board, 100 Action Cards, 24 Spell Cards, 100 Soul Deed Cards, 12 Pawns, and one black die. For 3-6 players.

name: No Trumps
description: With the No Trumps card game, gameplay is simple yet interesting and always entertaining. The "reader" reads off two quotes from the selected card. The other players then have to guess which quote was actually said by Donald Trump. The player with the fewest Trump cards after ten rounds is declared the winner.

name: Swivel
description:
Twist on the Classic Four-in-a-Row Game! It's full of secret colors, sneaky moves and wacky wild tokens that make you Swivel. Just when you think you're about to get four in a row, you or another player may have to twist a level of the 3D game board and change everything!

Players may move the upper level boards. Who gets 4-in-a-row first is the winner.

name: Journalist
description:
Morning in an unfamiliar room. Hotel. Headache. Buzzing phone. Roaring chief editor: "Where is the promised article? Where are you messing about?" Tangled language. Your gibbering voice can't stop this onslaught. "I don't care about your excuses! Get up and do something! I want to have a damn good story on the table right away. Otherwise you're fired!" Bashing phone resonates in your head even in the shower. Cold water slightly helps, and after a while you go into town to find something that will satisfy your boss.

In the game Journalist you assume the role of a reporter who writes articles at the last minute, then needs to deliver them to the editor. First, every player prepares a city on his own game plan in which the game takes place. During the game, you are composing words from letters and putting them on your own game plan. You must carefully plan where you put the letters to get more points or some other bonuses. The game is played simultaneously with a sand timer measuring the time. Thus, you are always pressed for time and must quickly work with your imagination and count with maze-like structure of the city which limits your possibilities.

Can you write a quality article and deliver it to the office earlier than others?
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Tile Placement
publishers: Bonaparte, Czech Board Games, Stragoo Games

name: Heimspiel: Das Bundesliga Manager-Spiel
description:
In Heimspiel 2 - 4 Players will be the managers of teams of the German Bundesliga. They buy players for their team to compete in single matches against other players or non player teams.

Every Team has a score. This, the result of a D20 roll and 3 event cards decide, which team has won, lost or if it is a tie.

Between the matches it is possible to buy new players in a silent auction.

In the end the player with the most points will win the game.

name: Race The Rails
description:
A quick-fire game of searching, moving and forfeits...but keep your elbows in!

Players are given a starting station and must then find it on one of the 36 journey cards (each has four stations): the entry will tell them the time of their next train and where it will take them (to be noted). Eventually, each player will see that their next station stop is HOME...those first home, with the most money, will win the game.

However, would that it were so simple! Along the way you may be accosted for your ticket, required to chase your connection, help other players on _their_ journey and/or enjoy a well-earned cup of tea (or even lunch!).

Race the Rails is an exhilarating game of speedy observation and dexterity for up to twelve simultaneous players.

—description from the publisher

Awards etc:
2020 - Nominated (finalist) for a Mojo Nation Play Creators Award - Game Designer of the Year (Licensed Product)
2022 - Short-listed for Gift of the Year Award - Branded Gift
categories: Exploration, Party Game, Racing, Real-time, Trains

name: Büro Crazy
description: Players engage in a series of duels aimed at positioning their pieces, which represent office workers, in positions of influence in the office. In a duel, the two players involved secretly allocate influence points and simultaneously reveal them, with the winner advancing their piece higher on the career ladder.

name: Money Card
description:
Players visit Europe and enjoy all the pleasures of a real vacation - souvenir hunting, sightseeing, betting at Monte Carlo and essential to this game's design: using American Express Traveler's Cheques.

Players race against one another to travel to 8 key cities in Europe: London, Copenhagen, Lisbon, Paris, Rome, Madrid, Vienna & Athens. In each city players collect Keys to the cities while trying not to run out of Traveler's Cheques.

Bonus moves are made by collecting Language cards and completing foreign phrases printed on the cards.

First player to show possession of their 8 Keys wins.

name: Sing Sing
description: Colored bars of two lengths (short and long) are placed randomly on the game board, which represents a prison. The colored bars are covering convict tiles. Each turn, one player closes his/her eyes, and another player removes a bar. The first player must then name the location, size, and color of the bar that was removed. If a convict has been totally freed from bars, he is awarded to the player that correctly named the removed bar, or the player who removed the bar, if the first player was incorrect. A player wins when he/she collects three convicts of the same type, or three different convicts.

name: ESPN All Sports Trivia Challenge
description:
If you love sports and think you know sports more than anyone else, then here’s your chance to prove it! Created by sports fans for sports fans, ESPN All Sports Trivia Challenge is an exciting and unpredictable head-to-head sports competition like no other!

To win, you’ll need more than sports knowledge and luck on your side because strategy is what separates this unique sports trivia game from the pack. Every move must be calculated – offense or defense – just like a real sports match up.

The object is to control a 25-box playing field by strategically picking questions and correctly answering them to win boxes and points, while blocking your opponent from doing the same.

There are 1,500 sports trivia questions jam-packed with facts and stats covering 10 sports categories, such as nicknames, football, baseball, basketball, golf and one that features ESPN-specific questions written by sports trivia legend Howard “Howie” Schwab
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports, Trivia

name: UNO: Marvel Heroes
description:
An Uno variation. This version features various Marvel Super Heroes and Villains.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The Feats of Fate card. When you play the Feats of Fate Card is played you can trade one of your cards to the first player in clock-wise order who has a Draw 4 Wild or Draw 2 card. If none of your opponents have one of the requested cards then you can play another card of your choice.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: The Whole Brain Game
description:
A player rolls an 8-sided die to determine which Instruction Card to use. For instance, on a roll of 6, the Instruction Card states "Draw One Category Card. Read the word from the GREEN Category. What would happen if there were no _____?"

The player follows the instructions from the Instruction card and selects the appropriate color from the Category Card. For instance, one Category Card has the word "Sound" in the GREEN Category.

The player then gives as many responses to the question posed before the 30 second timer runs out. For instance, the player may respond "There would be no telephones, no car mufflers, no music, no communication, no radio, no volume controls..."

Players earn points based on the number of acceptable responses. For instance, another player may disagree with "no communication" since it is quite possible to communicate without sound.

The first player/team to 80 points wins.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: The Celtic Game
description: Supposedly themed on a Celtic game called Tawlbwrdd (Throw-board), referred to the in the Howel Dha, this version greatly resembles the Viking game Hnefatafl. One set of pieces is on the outside of the board, trying to capture the other sides King. The King's army tries to protect his dash to the edge of the board and freedom. Moves are based on dice rolls. The board is styled with Celtic knot work designs. Rules in English, French and Japanese.

name: Coolympics
description:
The north pole animals hold their own athletic contests.

Intended for children Ages 5 and up.

name: Space Warrior
description:
User Summary

A simple tactical hex-and-counter game of small-scale boarding actions in space.

The counters represent individual combatants (referred to as "characters" in the rules). There can be up to twenty boarding and twenty defending characters. Each character is individually rated in four categories: Wounds, Offensive Class, Armor, and Weapons. The value for each category will range from 0-2 based on points assigned by the controlling player (four points are allotted to each character).

An optional rule allows for character advancement for every ten (!) missions a character survives (which seems like long odds in a game that is always a battle to the death). Other optional rules include written orders, facing, initiative determination for each unit, and a different allocation of character construction points for multi-player scenarios. Team play is offered as part of the scenario creation rules.

Rulebook Excerpts

You have received orders from Fleet Command to capture a ship and have jumped from your shuttle onto the landing bay of the enemy craft. The orders are repeated over the headset: "Capture the ship intact; no prisoners are to be taken." You do not know the reason for the order nor do you care. As mission commander, your sole concern is the successful completion of your mission with as few casualties as possible.

From your bunk you hear the klaxon blaring. Startled from sleep, you realize that your ship is under siege and listen for further orders. "They must not leave the ship alive." There is no time for questions; you only know that you must kill the invaders before they kill you.

Designers' Notes:

After carefully reviewing the board, it should be obvious that SPACE WARRIOR is a game of movement. Be careful not to stray too far from the wall that can provide cover or a hatchway that can provide escape. We strongly recommend the use of the optional rules. These rules enlivened the game during play-testing at the expense of only a few minutes of additional playing time.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Movement Points, Paper-and-Pencil, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Team-Based Game, Variable Set-up

name: Sherlock Holmes Game
description: A distant relative of Clue, where each player tries to deduce the Suspect, Motive, Crime Location and Weapon cards that were put in the Cemetary at the game's outset. Suspicion cards change hands, some are revealed to all, and so on. You win by correctly deducing the four hidden cards. Deduce incorrectly and you've lost, however.

name: Horton Hears A Who! Card Game
description: Cards are dealt out face-down in a 7x7 grid, representing the clover field. Hidden amongst the Clover cards are Who Cards, a special Who named Jo-jo, Jungle Animal Cards, and Beezle-Nut Oil Cards. Players flip cards starting at the outside edge and proceeding orthogonally until they collect a Who, or run into an Animal stopper. Cards are then re-flipped face down. Once a player finds three Who cards, he or she must then find the Jo-jo card to win the game. The game is designed for ages 4 and up.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy, Memory, Novel-based

name: Caçadores De Notícias
description: This game's objective is to run around the world reporting news. All the players are reporters trying to make money by being the first to get in the country where are the news.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Soccer
description: Each of the two players is a captain of a team. The team is represented by 11 wood units with a peg on them where a wood ball may sit. The soccer field is represented by circle spaces for movement. The active player rolls 2d6 to determine movement allowed. Movement allowance is spread out as desired between your players and determined by whether a player has the ball or not. It's all very simple, but works fantastic! Currently out of print.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Mountain Climb
description:
Two players face each other, place the game board between them, and place their pitons in their respective base camp. Roll to see who goes first. The first player rolls both dice and moves pitons the number of spaces indicated by the roll, using one die per piton (unless doubles are rolled, in which case both can be used for one piton). Moves must be made vertically and pitons must stay in their upward “trail”. If a player lands in the same space as the other player by exact count, the opponent's piton is sent back to start. The players take turns until one player reaches the summit with all five pitons!

Remember: Every Climb’s An Adventure… But There’s Only Room For One At The Top!

name: Technopoly
description:
Technopoly transports players from the familiar lanes of Monopoly's New Jersey to the bustling lands of Silicon Valley. Based on familiar rules and layout, this game offers much that is new. This game is similar to Monopoly but has more strategy and requires more choices.

The playing track is mostly two-way and has several sub-paths. Players compete for contracts with computer manufacturers, network developers, and military suppliers. The opportunities for following directions, problem-solving, and social brinkmanship are many. Jim McBurney has detailed each technology on the cards, but no knowledge of computers or technology is necessary for play, any more than you need a degree in hotel management to play Monopoly.

Some players may miss the familiar names like Board Walk or Marvin Gardens, but techies will appreciate being able to buy UNISYS "A" SERIES and XEROX ETHERNET.

name: Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire
description:
From the Introduction in the rules:

"It is Christmas Eve. You and your partner are sitting at the table. A glorious basket with chestnuts is waiting for you. You bring a toast and sip from your delicate Sierra Vista Zinfandel 1990. Next you light the cooking fire, and wait until it's hot enough. Then both of you put the first chestnuts on the fire. Oh, Christmas..."

Han Heidema gave out specially designed games as Christmas cards; one for every year from 1990 to 1999. This was card #7 and was sent out in 1996. It features artwork by Peter Mulder.

On their turn, each player will roll a die to determine the number of "Nut Points" (action points) available. These points are spent to cook one's own chestnuts without burning them and then to eat them, as well as to burn the other player's chestnuts. The game ends when all of one's player's chestnuts are burnt or eaten. Each eaten chestnut is one positive point and each burnt chestnut is one negative point. The player with the most points wins.

name: WOW! The Pillow Fight Game for Girls
description:
Back in the mid-1960s, Milton Bradley published a pair of wonderfully sexist games: WOW! (for girls) and POW! The Cannon Game for Boys. The games are essentially the same: dexterity games that consist of sending a small projectile over a barrier with the intent of knocking over the opponent's pieces.

The theme of WOW! is a pajama party. the playing pieces are girls engaging in a pillow fight and a house mother. The game board is divided into two sections by a cardboard barrier. Each side has a plastic bed with a small pillow. The bed acts as a catapult to send the pillow over the barrier. As described in the directions, WOW! is "a safe, fast-action game..."
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Party Game
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Milton Bradley

name: Word Battles
description:
Make your own crossword. Each turn a player chooses a letter, which both players have to use. Who makes the best words and scores the most points?

Two players have separate sectors of the game "board" (with a screen hiding it from the other player's view), each 5x5 squares in size. The players take turns announcing a letter that both have to place in their grid. When the entire grid is filled, players count their points (as in Scrabble, rarer letters count more; also, there are bonus points for words with 5 letters). The player with most points is the winner.

name: Huggermugger Jr.
description:
A Huggermugger game for a younger audience (9 and up). Players try to discover a "Mystery Word" (like Hangman). To move around the board they must correctly answer questions from the following categories: Scrambled Words, Spelling, Definition, and Luck of the Draw. Players learn the letters of the "Mystery Word" one at a time by reaching the "scoring arena" for that letter. Players may guess the word at any time, but an incorrect guess means that player is out of the game. First player to correctly guess the word wins.
Huggermugger Jr. has two sets of questions for two levels of difficulty. It has optional rules for playing along with some adults playing the regular Huggermugger game.

name: Madagascar
description:
Summary from the box:

"Alex and his friends are stranded on the island of Madagascar. Lucky for them, the Penguin's rescue boat will take them home, but YIKES, it's all the way at the other end of the island! Can you help them race across the island and get onto the boat safely? Steer clear of the Fossas, the dangerous animals lurking around! Be the first player to get to the rescue boat and win."

Components:

4 Character pawns: Alex, Marty, Gloria, and Melman. (Medium weight cardboard pieces in plastic bases.

12 Fossa pawns: 6 red, 6 green

Deck of 54 Cards. About half the size of a regular playing card, but about the same thickness.

1 Fossa die. 6 sided. two zeros, red two, red three, green four, green five.

Game board: Trifold. 15" x 30"

For 2-4 players, ages 6+

Game Play:
Each player puts their pawn on the start space and is dealt four cards face down. Cards are move 2, move 3, escape, special move 3, and cancel.

Each turn has two parts:

1. Roll Fossa die and move a correspondingly colored Fossa the required spaces.

2. Move a character pawn 1 space in any direction, OR play a card, OR trade three cards back to deck and get three new ones.

If a Fossa winds up on your spot, you are under attack. There are 2 ways to escape during your turn:

1. During part 1 roll the die and if you get the color matching the Fossa attacking you, you can just move it away.

2. Play an escape card. (Other players may play a cancel card on top of your escape card though.)

The first person to make it all the way to the boat wins.

Game play is approximately 30 mins or so depending on the number of players.

Play can be cut-throat. Escaping depends on luck rolling the correct number/color or drawing an escape card and no one playing a cancel card.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Last Man Standing
description:
Last Man Standing is a simultaneous-play gambling game. Cards representing fighters are played one per round over five rounds by each player and 'paid' with coins equal to their value. As fighters are defeated, their coins are collected by the winning fighter. Players also put coins in a pot which is won at the end of the fifth round by whichever players have surviving fighters. The player with the most money at the end wins the game.

Last Man Standing was first published as part of Chief Herman's Holiday Fun pack. It was conceived on a road trip across Eastern Washington as a cross between Lamarckian Poker and Dogfight.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Zero In
description: Listen to clues and try to Zero In on the names of the celebrities that they describe. Players take turns posing as celebrities, giving other players clues so that they can guess the celeb’s identity. Watch out! The clues can be tricky and you only get one guess for each celebrity. A player reads clues for other players until someone guesses the celebrity’s name or clues are exhausted. If you’re the first one to Zero In on the celebrity’s name, you win the points for the last clue read. The first player to reach 12 points wins.
publishers: Lone Shark Games, On The Spot Games

name: minizoomerz Basic Game
description:
minizoomerz - miniature racing on a grand scale

Game website : http://www.minizoomerz.com/

The minizoomerz Basic Game is a miniature motor racing game for 2-4 players aged 10years and up.

It is freely available as a print and play .pdf file from The Big Play's online store - http://www.thebigplay.co.uk/store

The 14 page .pdf file includes all the rules, tokens and counters you need to get started racing. A 'figure 8' circuit is included and introduces players to the Wild Canyons terrain. All you need to add are three six-sided dice.

Players can choose to move at fast speed to allow them to make maneuvers or go flat out at Furious speed. This decision dictates the number of dice they roll and the options they have during their move.

Players can pick up Fatigue during the race which can have an adverse effect on their performance at the later stages of the race. However, this can be managed and creates an ongoing 'risk assessment' aspect to the game in addition to choosing when to switch lanes and other situational decisions.

There is an accessory pack available for the game which includes 4 plastic miniature racing cars, 3 dice and 4 Special Ability cards which add an extra dimension to the games.

The Basic Game is also supported by expansion 'Toolkits', the first of which is the Wild Canyons which adds extra 'track sections' allowing players to design and create their own tracks and circuits.

Expanded by:

minizoomerz: Wild Canyons Toolkit
categories: Dice, Miniatures, Print & Play, Racing, Sports
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Phase Order

name: Trivial Pursuit: Holiday Edition
description:
Another expansion to the well known trivia game.
The questions all deal with topics like geography, destinations and other things related to traveling.

The box contains:
- 2400 questions and answers on
- 400 cards in
- 2 plastic boxes.

name: Rijkdommen van België
description: The goal of the game is to complete a circuit in Belgium (for example the gastronomical, sports, touristic, casino or economical circuit) faster than your opponents by traveling from city to city. This is done either by foot, bicycle or car. Money can be earned (to buy a bicycle or car) or lost during the game.

name: Space Tivitz
description:
Educational Math board game that uses checkers type movement. The playing pieces called a "Tivit" are 6 sided dice with each side having a symbol and numerical value. The 2 players race to reach the 9 planets. Each Planet has a mathematical operation(addition, subtraction, multiplication or division). A players score is the value of their tivit adjusted for the math operation for each tivit that lands on a planet.

The game includes 30 different paper boards with varying degrees of difficulty. For ages 8 and up.

name: Great Wally Word Search
description: This is Scrabble (and made by the same company) with a "Where's Wally?" overlay. Each player has their own foolscap-sized Where's Wally? picture (double-sided for 8 unique pictures). When forming words, all normal Scrabble rules and bonuses apply AS WELL AS scoring double if the word you spell can be recognized in your picture. You get a bonus 100 points for spelling (and finding) Wally.

name: Rumme
description:
The full title to the game was "Rumme - and Ten other good games."

This is a card game set offering a deck of cards with of other types than standard decks (Crowns and Shields in red, Helmets and Unicorns in black.) The decks are numbered from 1 to 13, and have two wild cards. The game rules within include Rumme, Turkette, Quenette, Goop, Argentina, Grafto, Baffle, Secret Seven, Reno, Rumme Baseall, and Flique.

In short this, like Rook, was designed to offer those who saw a deck of cards as gambling tools, and therefore bad, a chance to play several games with a safe deck of cards.

name: Take Your Pick: Movies, Music, & More
description:
Like the original Take Your Pick, this is a party game where one player is the subject and everyone else draws three cards, each of which has two choices on it A or B. The judges orient their cards in their hands such that they select one option from each card (turn the card one way, and the top word is circled, rotate it 180 degrees and the other word is circled).

In turn, each judge calls out the two words on one of his cards to the subject, who answers his preference. If the judge was correct, he keeps the card and continues. Wrong, and his turn ends. The subject gets the same score as the judge who got the most points this turn.

Quick and entertaining, which is what SimplyFun party games seem to be.

This edition includes entertainment choices (Batman or Spiderman, P Diddy or Led Zeppelin, etc).

name: Name Dropping
description:
From the back of the box:

Madonna, Coconuts, Mud Wrestling and a Naked Mole Rat... What do they all have in common? Absolutely nothing... except that they could all turn up during an outrageous game of Name Dropping!

Against the clock, you have to describe wildly diverse characters and objects to your team-mates... But beware of your opponents! They'll do ANYTHING to put you off and it's all within the rules!!

Fun, freaked, frustrating - it's a game to drive you bonkers!

name: Pocket Ungame: Families
description:
This is the Family version of Ungame. This set has new cards that are specifically designed for siblings and parents to get to know each other better and explore each other's feelings.

There are 140 cards divided into two decks of 70 cards each. The first deck contains lighter questions such as, "If our family inherited a million dollars, I would like for us to _______." Most of the questions in the first deck are about families in general and not about individual members of the family. The second deck is composed of more specific questions, such as describing your feelings about other family members or explaining how you felt when a family-member hurt your feelings. Other cards allow the player to talk about any subject they choose.

Players take turns drawing cards and answering the questions on them in a few sentences. Most of the rules are considered as guidelines, such as the "hint" to keep your answers fairly short, but the Rule of Silence during another player's answer must be observed.

As with other games in the Ungame series, there is no winner or loser. The object of the game is to spend quality time with your family and learn more about the thought and feelings of those closest to you.

name: Mr. Kongo
description:
The first player to nab 25 bananas is the winner—but the only way to earn bananas is to predict in advance how many of the yellow fruits you'll be able to get by the end of the round.

(Summary from Boardgame News)

This is a poker-like game where players must make a contract in order to earn points. Schmidt Spiele have arbitrarily laid over this a jungle theme.

Players draw and discard cards in order to achieve particular sets, using their hand cards and a one-card flop. Some of these combinations are comparative—highest and lowest total of card face value around the table—but in order to earn points from them the players must predict the exact number they will earn.

name: Junior Colorino
description: Junior Colorino is a one player game for small children to help them learn their primary colors. The child basically needs to place the color chip on the correct space on the board. Four different boards (sheets) are included with different pictures on each. One side of each board has the picture in color while the other side has it in black and white.

name: Piggy
description:
The cards are thoroughly shuffled and a dealer deals each player 4 cards. Remaining cards are placed in the centre of the table. The object in Piggy is to collect all four cards the same. The first player decides on a card they don;t want and pass it to the player on their left. Play continues, with players deciding on whether to draw a new card from the deck or pass one of their own. Once a player has collected their set of 4, they stick out their tongue! As other players notice, they follow suit. The last person to notice receives a letter token P, I, G, G, or Y. The winner is the last person in, with the least number of letters.
Shorter versions can be played by just playing to P, I, G or deciding on how many rounds to play before starting.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Virginia Techopoly
description:
A HOKIE GAME!
Have you ever fantasized about being the Hokie Bird? Or dreamed of owning Lane Stadium? If so, here’s your chance to do it all! VA TECHOPOLY is designed for alumni, students and fans of Virginia Tech. Choose your token and advance to Register and Proceed. You may soon be marching in the Corps of Cadets…or hanging out at Cook’s Laundromat!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Don't Tip the Waiter
description:
Players start the game with three one-dollar bills. They then take turns selecting any size plate of food and placing it on the waiter’s tray. If the added plate makes the waiter tip and drop any of his plates, the player has to “tip” the waiter one dollar. A player is out of the game when he or she runs out of money. The last player with money remaining wins the game.

Very similar in theme and name to Don't Tip the Waiter and Don't Tip The Waiter.

name: Goko no Saikoro
description:
Goko no Saikoro (五個の骰子) is a dice game that was designed with the goal to give players more strategic options and control of the game than is usually the case in dice games. A secondary goal was to make a dice game that is not completely multiple solitaire. The resulting game is played with 5 dice, hence the name, which is Japanese for '5 dice'.

Every turn a player decides what 'development' he or she wants to roll for. These 'developments' change the nature of the game. Some allow re-rolling a die, others change how the dice-roll result is converted into a score or points. To achieve a certain development, at least a certain score has to be rolled. This required score increases with each development achieved. If a player rolls particularly high he/she can choose to take points rather than achieve the development he/she was rolling for. If there are no more developments available, the player must roll for points. The game ends when one player chooses to take points for the tenth time. The game takes about 10 minutes per player.

name: Pingo no i
description: From the game's manual: Pingo no i is an intelligent and fun card game of letters ideal to develop creativity and vocabulary of adults and children. Find out the several ways to play it and start creating words.

name: AGE: The Amazing Goal Era
description:
Collectible card game based on fantasy soccer.

Players have to build an 11 cards deck (10 players and 1 goalkeeper) and use them in a soccer match.

Athletes in AGE are fantasy creatures such as elves, orcs, minotaurs and much more.

Dice rolling is used to determine the outcome of the various actions (pass, shoot, defend and so on).

Published in Italy.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Sports

name: Eggheads
description:
A board game for fans of the popular TV show
Format: five "amateur quizzers" take on five quiz professionals in a big money quiz
Tests your general knowledge
Comprises actual questions posed on the show

name: Umbra
description:
DESCRIPTION:
The goal of Umbra is to move all five of your pieces to your victory zone. There are two players, North and South. Each player has five pieces. North's pieces are concave, South's pieces are convex. There are two zones on the board. Each zone consists of five positions marked by a nearby colored circle. The zones serve two purposes. At the start of game, each player takes turns placing their pieces in their starting zone. North's starting zone is at the top of the board, South's starting zone is at the bottom. North's starting zone is South's victory zone, and similarly, South's starting zone is North's victory zone. Once the placement phase has completed, the player's take turns moving one of their stones. The first player to move all of their pieces to the victory zone such that all piece colors match the color markings of the victory zone, wins.

Umbra has a puzzle like quality to it.

PIECE MOVEMENT:
Once all pieces have been placed, a piece can move in one of the follwing ways:

STEP move - The piece can move to any adjacent position.
JUMP move - The piece can perform a non-capturing jump over an enemy piece as long as the target position advances the piece towards the victory zone.
SWAP move - If your piece is adjacent to an enemy piece and the enemy piece is in your victory zone, the positions of the two pieces are exchanged.
Note: To make the move, drag your piece and drop it over the enemy piece.

name: Flipp!
description:
Flipp! is a game where you came up with words that are difficult for the opposing team to explain.

Players are divided in two teams. Then dice are rolled to determine which letters teams have to use in their words. Then hourglasses are turned and teams formulate words based on the letters given earlier. The opposing teams has exactly the same amount of time to figure out the words that your team spent formulating them.

A team gets a point for every word they guess. For every word that is not guessed the opposing team gets two points. Both teams have a pawn that is moved forwards on a game board when they score points. The first team to make it to the finish is the winner.

The Nordic version has seven dice of which four are language dependant.

This game is actually an early version of Tic Talk and Wordy Word; in later versions the dice have become d12's, otherwise it's pretty much the same game.

name: 3 SPORT GAMES
description:
Simulation of 3 sport games: soccer, basketball, hockey.

Players subsequently move all they players.

Soccer: Each player has 10 players and goalkeeper on the pitch. Goalkeeper cannot move out of penalty area. During each turn players can run with ball (max. 6 hexes), pass to another man (at most for 10 hexes) or shoot (max. 10 hexes). Each pass can be blocked if opponent is next to the line of the pass. If on the line of the pass - opponent always steals the ball. Rules saving a shot by goalkeeper are the same, but there's possibility to score the goal even if he's on the line of the shot. There are also tackles, fouls, outs and penalties, but no yellow/red cards.

Basketball: each player has 5 players. Players can move at most 3 hexes (no dice rolling), shoot, or pass.
